Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Carbon Sequestration & Waste Management for College Campuses & Larger Facilities
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer Research Phase I project is to use waste to produce clean, green energy. The proposed technology diverts waste material from landfills while sequestering carbon and can be used in many other industries such as food waste, forestry biomass and disaster relief. For example, wildfires are becoming an annual threat that destroys large portions of states and thousands of homes. The proposed technology can reduce wildfire risk by cleaning up the forest undergrowth. Landfills in many states will be reaching maximum capacity in coming years and are under threat of being shut down: diverting landfill waste to the production of valuable products is much desired. Besides municipal waste, it is also possible to reduce the burning of agricultural waste by converting these waste streams into valuable outputs, such as biofuels and biochar for use in applications including concrete and water filtration. A significant amount of carbon is sequestered in this process which can earn additional carbon credits to the operator.<br/><br/>The proposed project will develop a low-pressure hydrothermal liquefaction Inclined Rotary Gasifier (IRG). The project will optimize its outputs to further clean up the liquid & gas product streams from heavy metal contaminants such as Cu, Pb, Hg, Ni, Zn, and Cd, and high concentrations of other contaminants. Phase I research will focus on developing the process to remove up to 90% of the original concentration of these contaminants without compromising the syngas energy content. This will require maximizing the biochar production rate. These rates are typically lower than those when biomass is used as a feedstock. Hence a detailed investigation into the system's thermal efficiency will be undertaken with an aim to increase it. This may require increasing the heat transfer rates through design modifications and the choice of operating conditions. The bio-oil and water (from the high-pressure dewatering system) will also be cleaned by the biochar produced by the same municipal solid waste feedstock.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Performance_Institution.Name: State University of New York, Cobleskill Campus

POR.DRECONTENT:
Caribou Biofuels, Inc. is commercializing an innovative, patented gasifier technology, the Inclined Rotary Gasifier (IRG), that was initially developed by The Research Foundation for the State University of New York (SUNY RF) at the Cobleskill campus for use by the US Army. The IRG is a waste-to-energy solution that converts various types of waste/biomass feedstocks (e.g., agricultural, forestry, municipal solid waste, plastics) into valuable, climate-friendly outputs (e.g., liquid biofuels, gas for electricity and heat, and biochar).

The IRG process leverages nature's carbon cycle, where plants metabolize carbon dioxide (CO2) from the atmosphere through photosynthesis. When plants die, decompose, or burn, they release the stored carbon back into the atmosphere. The IRG transforms the stored carbon in biomass into biofuels, biopower and bioproducts, thereby displacing fossil fuels that still dominate electric power generation, transportation, and industry and are one of the primary drivers of global carbon emissions. In addition to producing bioenergy that can offset fossil fuel use, the IRG technology processes waste that would otherwise end up in landfills and permanently sequesters carbon in the form of biochar.

Caribou Biofuels' National Science Foundation STTR Phase I project was focused on identifying and developing small-scale mechanical processes to ensure that materials of concern that may be present in biomass and fed to the IRG (e.g., heavy metals and other contaminants) are completely eliminated in the system and do not return to the environment where they could pose an exposure risk to humans. The ultimate goal of the project was to certify safe, documented, and quantifiable IRG operations that meet local, state, national, and international standards. Meeting these standards and the related permitting is a critical aspect to IRG operations in the field.

Using lead (Pb) as an indicator, the Caribou Biofuels team performed a variety of different tests to understand where heavy metals accumulate in the IRG system and how to capture them. Biochar (a byproduct of the IRG process), activated carbon, and organoclay were used to capture lead particulates that get trapped in the IRG's quencher tank due to a sharp drop in temperature. Accumulation in a single tank is a crucial advantage in this capture process. Adsorption rates as high as ~62% were achieved for biochar harvested directly from the process without any upgrades. Organoclay was observed to reduce the lead content in the quencher tank by over 94%.

 A filtering system was designed and outlined for fabrication in Phase II which will continuously extract oil using these methods and concentrate it in these filters, essentially taking heavy metals out of the feedstock that would otherwise leach into the ground at landfills or pollute the air during prescribed biomass burns for wildfire prevention. Five key factors in accelerating adsorption rates were discovered and are maximized in the filtration system design. Other heavy metals found in biomass such as arsenic (As), cadmium (Cd), chromium (Cr), and zinc (Zn) have similar thermal properties and are expected to behave the same in the system. Phase II will examine their respective capture rates using the same methods developed in Phase I. The lead captured in the various media may be feasible to react into a salt or another marketable product, which will be further explored in Phase II.

Caribou Biofuels is extremely grateful for the support of the National Science Foundation. This project provided crucial data around heavy metals and contaminants that has allowed us to enhance our system and get one step closer to commercialization. Once commercialized, the versatile IRG technology is destined for adoption around the world, where it will contribute to significant greenhouse gas mitigation, generating new value streams from biomass waste and helping to mitigate the climate crisis.


Last Modified: 04/13/2022
Modified by: Kieran Mitchell
